content:
I am currently a postdoctoral researcher working with Dr. Reiko Mazuka at RIKEN CBS Laboratory for Language Development (previously at Dr. Krista Byers-Heinlein's Concordia Infant Research Laboratory). My main research interests are centered around infant language development, bilingualism, and cross-cultural/cross-language differences. I am particularly interested in studying how differences in language environment influence early language development.
One thing I enjoy doing in research is analyzing and visualizing data. Often time I’m amazed by what the data tells us about language development in infants.
On a side note, I am also multilingual. Growing up in Hong Kong, I speak Cantonese, English, and Mandarin Chinese; I also learned Japanese since teenage years.
Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions relating to my research.
Rachel :)

content: In this experiment, we are investigating bilingual toddlers‚Äô learning of cross-language synonyms (i.e., translation equivalents) in immediate translated sentences versus single language sentences. Bilingual toddlers‚Äô word learning will be assessed with an online asynchronous experiment.
title: The effect of Language switching on bilingual toddlers' word learning

summary: Here we present a novel approach that models translation equivalent knowledge as a function of bilinguals‚Äô own vocabulary size in each language. Our novel insight is that learning a translation equivalent pair can be described as the joint probability of learning each of the words in the pair.
title: Translation equivalents aren't special in bilingual vocabulary development: A quantitative model

authors: Lori Mitchell, Rachel K.Y. Tsui, & Krista Byers-Heinlein
summary: Our findings revealed that form-similar cognates are produced more readily in bilingual infant vocabulary development than non-cognate translation equivalents: effects are small at younger ages, and grow over time.
title: Bilingual infants learn cognates more rapidly than non-cognates

summary: Study 1 explored patterns of translation equivalent learning under a novel computational model ‚Äî the Bilingual Vocabulary Model ‚Äî which quantifies translation equivalent knowledge as a function of the probability of learning words in each language, and includes a bias parameter that varies the difficulty of learning translation equivalents according to each account. Study 2 tested model-derived predictions against vocabulary data from 200 French‚ÄìEnglish bilingual children aged 18‚Äì33 months.
title: Are translation equivalents special? Evidence from simulations and empirical data from bilingual infants

content: Bilingual infants grow up with the unique experience of needing to learn two words for most concepts. These words are called translation equivalents, and translation equivalents that also sound similar (e.g., banana-banane) are called cognates. Research has consistently shown that children and adults process cognates more easily than non-cognates. The present study explored if there is such an advantage for cognate production in bilingual‚Äôs early vocabulary development.
summary: Longitudinal evidence from French-English bilingual infants of 16-30 months
title: Cognate advantage in bilingual infants

content: The acquisition of translation equivalents is often considered a special component of bilingual children‚Äôs vocabulary development, as bilinguals have to learn words that share the same meaning across their two languages. This study examined three contrasting accounts for bilingual children‚Äôs acquisition of translation equivalents relative to words that are first labels for a referent: the Avoidance Account whereby translation equivalents are harder to learn, the Preference Account whereby translation equivalents are easier to learn, and the Neutral Account whereby translation equivalents are similar to learn. To adjudicate between these accounts, we put forward a computational model ‚Äî the Bilingual Vocabulary Model ‚Äî which proposes that the number of translation equivalents bilingual children produce is a function of vocabulary learning in each language, in the context of the number of potentially learnable words given the children‚Äôs developmental level.
summary: Evidence from simulations and empirical data from bilingual infants
title: Are translation equivalents special?

summary: Collaboration between Concordia Infant Research lab and Princeton Baby Lab
title: Bilingual Families Project

content: Infants begin life with a remarkable ability to discriminate a wide range of phonetic contrasts, both native and non-native. Within the first year of life, infants‚Äô phonetic discrimination ability undergoes a significant reorganization from being language-general to being language-specific. However, the developmental pattern is actually more complex than previously thought: Certain contrasts can only be discriminated in the second half of the first year. This project probes Cantonese-learning infants‚Äô ability to discriminate lexical tones in their native language. Lexical tones are considered an expansion of the phoneme inventory in a tone language, where pitch variations also signal lexical meaning differences. Through Cantonese which contrasts its lexical tones through changes in pitch height and pitch contour, this project examines how the development of lexical tone perception in Cantonese-learning infants is affected by the pitch characteristics of lexical tones.
summary: Investigating whether all lexical tones are treated as equal by native tone-learning infants
title: Development of tone perceptions in Cantonese-learning infants

summary: Using a language-switching paradigm, this study investigated differences in phonetic transfer of Cantonese‚ÄìEnglish bilingual adults with various language dominance profiles (Cantonese-dominant, English-dominant, and balanced bilinguals).
title: Impact of language dominance on phonetic transfer in Cantonese‚ÄìEnglish bilingual language switching

summary: Hong Kong Cantonese provides a fascinating case to the study of prosody because of its rich inventory of sentence-final particles (SFPs) that carry two levels of prosodic information: an inherent lexical tone and intonation. The present study examined the effect of the interaction between tone and intonation on the production of SFPs among native Cantonese speakers.
title: An acoustic study on the effect of the interaction between intonation and lexical tones on the realization of Cantonese sentence-final particles

summary: This study examined the longitudinal relation between early prosodic reading and later reading comprehension ability in Cantonese English-learning elementary school children.
title: Prosodic reading and reading comprehension in Chinese and English among Hong Kong Cantonese-English bilingual children: A longitudinal study

summary: We examine the role of prosodic reading in English reading comprehension among Cantonese-English bilingual children by characterizing the acoustic characteristics of bilingual children's English prosodic production and relating them to their English reading comprehension.
title: The role of prosodic reading in English reading comprehension among Cantonese-English bilingual children
